name: Common Hill Myna
description: The hill myna is unmistakable. Its glossy metallic black feathers contrast with white wing patches and yellow, bare wattled lobes on the cheeks and nape. The beak is orange.
spread_note: In many subspecies across the southern Indian subcontinent, including most of Indonesia
food_note: Ripe fruits, to a lesser extent invertebrates
image_alt: Common Hill Myna, photo: Prague Zoo Archive
proportions: Body length 17–29 cm; tail length 7–8 cm; wing length 15.5–17.5 cm; weight 190–310 g
attractions: Despite its somewhat exotic appearance, the hill myna cannot deny its kinship with starlings. Like our common starling, it easily adapts to human presence. Outside the breeding season, it stays in small groups, mainly in tree canopies, foraging for fruits, especially favoring figs. It also feeds on buds, nectar, insects, and occasionally catches a lizard. The male boasts a fairly wide vocal range, though not particularly melodic. Hill mynas kept in households readily learn to mimic various tunes and even whole sentences.
breeding: We have kept hill mynas since 1989.
